title: Where to See Cape Buffalo in Africa
text:

You should have no problem spotting l arge herds of buffalo in most of Africa's major national parks , but some places are definitely better than others for sheer numbers. Seeing huge herds of several hundred strong is always impressive. Watch out for the big old males (dugga boys) because they can be aggressive! Buffalo are not as endangered as many other larger mammals in Africa, but their numbers are certainly dwindling in areas where human population pressures are at their highest. They tend to carry diseases that can be passed on (and are often fatal) to domestic cattle. Here are the top National Parks and Conservancies where you have an excellent chance of seeing large herds of Cape Buffalo, one of Africa's " Big Five ". Anouk Zijlma 1. Chobe National Park, Botswana 
Chobe National Park and the greater Chobe, Savute and Linyanti areas in the north west region of Botswana are renowned for its large herds of buffalo . These two picture here blocked us from getting back to our lodge after a sunset cruise. Lions in this area have been known to specialize in hunting buffalo - quite a sight to see. During the dry season in particular, large herds come to visit from neighboring Zimbabwe and Namibia . Many lodges and camps in this area overlook rivers, channels or waterholes and you'll likely see buffalo coming to drink. More » David Hutchinson 2. Lower Zambezi National Park, Zambia 
The concentration of rage herds of Cape Buffalo around the Zambezi River is impressive and there's nowhere better to enjoy them than in the Lower Zambezi National Park . Many of the camps and lodges located on the banks of the river afford guests wonderful opportunities to see large herds of elephant at play, right from their rooms, canoes, fishing boats, and communal camp areas. 
South Luangwa is also a stellar place to view huge herds of buffalo. More » 3. Okavango Delta, Botswana 
The Okavango river cuts through the center of Botswana's K alahari Desert, creating a unique inland water system that gives life to a huge variety of birds and mammals, including large herds of buffalo. Most of the land based camps in the Okavango offer excellent sightings. Buffalo can't be too far from fresh water, so this is a perfect area for them year round. As the floods recede from October - March, you may find it more difficult to spot herds as there's more land for them to roam around on. More » 4. Greater Kruger Area, South Africa 
There is a very healthy population of Cape Buffalo in the Greater Kruger area, more than 10,000 individuals call it home. You can see Buffalo in the national park, as well as the private concessions bordering the National Park, they include: Sabi Sand Reserve , Manyaleti, and Timbavati. More » Anouk Zijlma 5. Amboseli National Park, Kenya 
Located in the south of Kenya , Amboseli lies on the Tanzanian border, in the shadows of Mount Kilimanjaro . Amboseli attracts visitors primarily because of its huge herds of elephant, but also buffalo. Very picturesque with the Mount Kilimanjaro backdrop. The park is also home to many predators like lion, cheetah and leopard. A natural swamp, fed by the melting snows of Kilimanjaro makes it attractive for buffalo to stay in this area year round. More » Anouk Zijlma 6. Serengeti, Tanzania 
The Serengeti is a good bet for "Big Five" enthusiasts, with plenty of Buffalo to be seen along the western corridor near the Grumeti River and in the wooded Seronera areas. Buffalo need to be within a relatively short distance of water, so sadly the northern Serengeti has not seen huge herds in quite a while. Buffalo also prefer woodland areas, not the wide open savanna. More » More About Cape Buffalo ... Cape buffalo are large, adults stand 4-6 feet tall and males weigh in at around 700 kg's (1500 lb's). Even lions don't dare take a chunk out of this beast unless they have friends helping them. Cape Buffalo are said to have killed more big game hunters than any other animal in Africa and are one of Africa's most dangerous animals. On the more open grasslands, Cape buffalo appear in large herds that can number up to a thousand individuals. Remarkably, there are few scuffles between herd members, perhaps the large males with their strong curved horns realize they could seriously injure one another in a brawl. Males will fight for dominance, but the battles are brief. Cape Buffalo need to drink every day, so are often found close to water and never in the desert. They prefer to eat tall, coarse grass as well as bushes. Cape buffalo numbers are shrinking because they are hunted for their meat, and they have also been the victims of various domestic cattle diseases. There are thought to be around 1 million Cape buffalo left in Africa.
